nitrating phenol directly as a substrate is extremely difficult without a ton of side products. The order of addition of the reagents in a picric acid synth, where phenol is first dissolved in sulfuric acid, is to sulfonate the phenol to form p-phenolsulfonic acid which is much more receptive to a good clean nitration than phenol is. I wonder if you could've perhaps sulfonated the phenol first and used an organic solvent to carry out the nitration at low temperature. More importantly, with a sulfonic acid group blocking the para position, ortho-nitrophenol would be almost exclusively the product.

For the m-nitrophenol you have to go with Nitrobenzene and then sulphonate it with concentrated H2SO4 and after this melt the 1-nitro-3-sulphobenzoic acid with NaOH and then add some HCl to eliberate the m-nitrophenol. :)

to make m-nitrophenol: this was just a pathway I thought up with reagents a home chemist should have easy access to. start with benzene, react with nitric acid and sulfuric acid to add an NO2 group. then purify this. remembering that this group is meta directing (I think) for further electrophilic addition, chlorinate with chlorine gas and AlCl3 as a catalyst. you should end up with chlorine in the meta position. then react with sodium hydroxide. this sodium hydroxide will make the solution basic enough to occur. this should give you m-nitrophenol. But you could probably find a much more efficient pathway.

Start with benzene, add the  nitro group first by EAS (HNO3/H2SO4) . The N=O bond makes the nitro an electron withdrawing group causing a partial negative charge in the meta positions. Then add electrophilic form of OH (most likely explosive). The partial negative charge on the nitro benzene in the meta positions will direct the positive charged OH electrophile to the meta positions in a second EAS.
That's a heck of a mess you have yourself there!  (..sloppy lab practices aside)

Adding nitro group first will be a very slow reaction. I assume adding a stronger activator in the para position of phenol, and then adding the nitro group. Once it's on there you just need to remove the new activator.

For m-nitrophenol I would start with nitrobenzene, next Friedle-Craft reaction to make m-cloronitrobenzene, next melting with KOH

For m-Nitrophenol you'd need a group with a -M-effect on the benzene ring. So anything in which the first atom (counted from the ring) of the substituent has a double bond to the next atoms. -COOH, -CHO or -COOR would be suitable. I think Benzoic acid would be the most sensible option.

The concept is an electrophylic aromatic addition (EAS) with the starting reagents nitrobenzene, sulfuric acid and water.
m-Nitrophenol is "easily" synthesised from nitrobenzene in with sulfuric acid and water. Nitrobenzene is a meta-director and with some heating the protonated water will react on the meta position of the nitrobenzene.

This reaction looks extremely messy. What I would have done is do a test reaction with 1/10 of the phenol, and then scale it up if it does work. Also an alternative procedure could be done by slowly adding nitric acid to an excess of phenol. This promotes mono-nitration, and may result in less side products (or it might fail completely, but that is part of experimentation) The separation and purification of products could be done by column chromatography, the ortho and para isomers have great separation, and I would guess that the tar and the unreacted phenol would also separate well. This would have the added benefit of recovering the unreacted phenol.

My organic chemistry is rather rusty so forgive me for any gross errors in logic, but here's how I would approach it:

Start with benzene, then nitrate once. From there, we halogenate the ring (since the NO2 is strongly deactivating- i.e. meta directing). From there, we can turn the halogen group into an OH group by performing nucleophilic aromatic substitution with something like sodium hydroxide and then treating with a monoprotic acid like HCl. That SHOULD give us m-nitrophenol, but I could be mistaken- I enjoyed pchem much more than ochem :P

Source used: Organic Chemistry 7th ed. by Bruice, P (pretty much all of chapter 19).

You kinda said the answer to your ending-question earlier on in the video ;)
The hydroksyl group of phenol is activating, so o/p-directing. If we on the other hand start of with nitrobenzene, and add a hydroksyl group to this, we will mostly get the meta product. Nitro groups are deactivating, as the nitrogen is pretty electron-poor because of the two oxygens bonded to it. It will therefore pull electrons from the aromatic ring. This opens up the meta positions. Getting on the hydroksyl group can be done in many different ways.
Final product is thus m-nitrophenol
For your question, I would start with m-nitroaniline reacts with sodium nitrite and hydrochloric acid to form azide salt, follow by water workup which produces phenol. :)

I felt a bit pained watching your synthesis, you lost a lot of product through water. I think there are a few improvements to increase the yield of the product. First, we can use concentrated HNO3 and H2SO4 to make the reaction process better which work well in organic solvent like DCM; you don't have to use so much sulfuric acid (which probably cause the tar to form from the phenol) since the hydrogensulfate ion is a good base which will deprotonate the transition state to form back sulfuric acid; plus water can affect the concentration of nitric acid formed which reduce the efficiency of the reaction... After the reaction, you can quench the reaction with some ice water to dilute the mixture, wash the aqueous layer with some organic solvent and then wash the organic layer with NaHCO3 (small amount would do) then dry over salt and magnesium sulfate (the typical work up), then rotavap and you'll have a good mixture of two mono-nitrated product.... For the tar, it can even separated well if you dissolve the products in the organic solvent and filter it over celite (or filter paper)...

Interesting question. My idea would be to nitrate aniline, with stoichiometic sulfuric acid. In a strongly acidic solution, the aniline will get protonated to anilinium. The protonated nitrogen substituent on the ring is strongly electron withdrawing, and so a majority of the nitrated product made will be the meta product. The m-nitroaniline made can be diazotized and hydrolyzed to the m-nitrophenol.

Another approach would be to nitrate a ketone without alpha hydrogens (benzophenone?), and then perform a Bayer-Villager oxidation on the product to get a phenol.

I would start with Benzene and sulfonate with Oleum to get Benzenesulfonic Acid, Then Nitrate this with HNO3/H2SO4 (it probably would only get nitrates once, in meta-position) and then add it to molten NaOH, which would covert the -SO3H to -OH.
